 Continuous Safety Improvement Efforts
	
	WTG’s Environmental, Health, and Safety Management System forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:
	
-	The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, or equipment are considered.
-	The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) review serves as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential process hazards and verification of safeguards, thereby leading to continual improvements in process safety and safe work practices.
-	The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.
-	Incident Investigation procedures are in place to ensure that corrective and/or preventative measures are taken as applicable following an incident.  This ensures that process design, operating equipment, and operating and maintenance safe work practices are evaluated to determine changes needed to prevent the recurrence of an incident.
-	Internal and third-party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements with any action items tracked to completion. 
-	An annual dialogue with the Upton County LEPC will ensure a readiness to respond

-	Conducting periodic operational rounds to ensure problems are detected and corrected in a timely manner.
	
	Five-Year Accident History
	
	The facility has experienced one incident during the last five years that is reportable in the five-year accident history maintained under the RMP regulations.  The incident occurred in April 2020 and resulted in significant on-site property damage at the #6 recompressor.  There have been no other releases of RMP-regulated substances that have resulted in onsite injuries, deaths, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage within the past five years .

The RMP flammable substances and mixtures stored or processed at the facility are the flammable mixture comprised of methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, isopentane, and pentane, which is being processed through the plant; as well as propane, which is used as refrigerant in the cryogenic process. There are no toxic substances present at the facility in amounts greater than threshold quantity.  

WTG has determined that the gas plant should be considered one process under the RMP rule.  This facility has one process (as defined by the regulation) consisting of a flammable mixture and propane.  Although the systems containing the flammable mixture and the propane are not interconnected, an incident in one of the systems could trigger a release in the other system, therefore, the two systems are to be considered one process (see definition of “process” at 40 CFR 68.3).

WTG has determined that SGP is classified as a Program Level 3 facility under the RMP regulation because the nearest public receptor is within the worst-case scenario flammable endpoint radius and the facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard.  


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response 

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by WTG.  These high standards include:

-	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
-	Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility, operator training, and intervention.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)

Introduction and Policies

WTG South Permian Midstream LLC (WTG) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while complying with applicable laws and regulations.  WTG’s management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental, Health, and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, and emergency response in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility and continuous improvement efforts to improve safety at the facility.

Non-Responding Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

WTG owns and operates a natural gas processing plant located near Midkiff, Texas.  The Sonora Gas Plant (SGP) compresses and treats natural gas to produce residue gas (methane) and natural gas liquids (NGL).  After processing, the residue gas and NGL exit the plant via product pipelines.  

Pre-treated, sweet field gas enters the plant via a pipeline, is dehydrated, and sent to the NGL recovery plant.  At the recovery plant, gas is routed to a demethanizer tower, which separates it into a residue gas product stream and an NGL product stream.  The NGL stream is purified using an amine treater, which removes carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulfide.  SGP uses a flare to burn gases during emergency/upset conditions, system maintenance, and startup and shutdown.
